documentType: Bureau of Prisons incident report and memoranda
summary: This document is a collection of Bureau of Prisons forms and memoranda detailing the discovery, medical response, and aftermath of Jeffrey Epstein's death by apparent suicide in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York, on August 10, 2019. It includes the initial incident report, staff accounts of the response, medical records, and a unit roster.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The inmate found unresponsive in his cell at MCC New York on August 10, 2019, and later pronounced deceased. The documents detail the medical emergency response to his apparent suicide.

persons.name: Tova Noel
persons.context: Listed as a staff member involved in the incident report with no reported injury.

persons.name: Michael Thomas
persons.context: Listed as a staff member involved in the incident report with no reported injury.

persons.name: Robert Beaudouin
persons.context: MD requested to cosign a medical consultation request for Epstein's cardiac arrest.

persons.name: Officer Dupree
persons.context: Asked for an AED during the medical emergency response on 9 South.

persons.name: Officer Cale
persons.context: Brought a stretcher to 9 South during the medical emergency response.

persons.name: Senior Officer Specialist K. Cale
persons.context: Responded to the medical emergency on 9 South, witnessed CPR, assisted in transport, and followed the ambulance to the hospital.

persons.name: Director Wiggins
persons.role: Director, Office of City Medical Examiner (OCME)
persons.context: Communicated with regarding the transportation of Epstein's remains to the city morgue.

connections.description: Noel is listed as staff on the incident report for the event involving Epstein's death.
Thomas is listed as staff on the incident report for the event involving Epstein's death.
Beaudouin was requested to cosign a medical consultation for Epstein's cardiac arrest.

events.title: Discovery of Epstein Unresponsive
events.description: At approximately 6:33 a.m., Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell (cell #220, 9 South SHU) at MCC New York while staff were serving breakfast.

events.title: Medical Response and Transport
events.description: Staff initiated CPR, called EMS, and transported Epstein to the Health Services unit. EMS arrived at 6:43 a.m., and he was transported to New York Presbyterian – Lower Manhattan Hospital at approximately 7:10 a.m.

events.title: Pronouncement of Death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was pronounced deceased at the hospital at 7:36 a.m. due to cardiac arrest.

events.title: Remains Transported to Morgue
events.description: Epstein's remains were prepared by hospital staff, moved to the hospital morgue, and later transported to the city morgue by the Office of the City Medical Examiner (OCME) staff at 12:57 p.m.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (150 Park Row, New York, NY 10007)
New York Presbyterian – Lower Manhattan Hospital (170 William Street, New York, NY 10038)
City Morgue (Office of City Medical Examiner)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at MCC New York on August 10, 2019, at approximately 6:33 a.m. and was pronounced dead at 7:36 a.m.
The incident report lists the method as 'Hanging/Asphyxiation' and the cause of the incident as 'Suicide'.
Medical staff noted 'circumferential bruising around the neck' and 'posterior mottling' upon finding Epstein.
Staff were instructed not to speak to anyone or the media about the situation and to direct inquiries to the MCC NY Public Relations Officer.
The documents include a unit roster for August 10, 2019, showing Epstein was housed in cell '204-206LAD' on the roster.
